==Chinese==
{{zh-forms}}

===Glyph origin===
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|水|alt1=氵|工|ls=psc|c1=s|c2=p}}.

===Etymology===
“[[Yangtze]] River”.

Borrowed from a substrate [[Mon-Khmer]] language; compare {{bor|zh|mkh-pro|*ruŋ|*ruŋ ~ ruuŋ ~ ruəŋ|river|notext=1}} > {{cog|mkh-vie-pro|*k-roːŋ||river}} ({{cog|vi|sông}}), {{cog|mnw|ကြုၚ်|tr=krɜŋ||small river, creek}}.

Derivative: {{och-l|港|harbour}}.

===Definitions===
{{zh-hanzi}}

# {{lb|zh|geography}} The [[Yangtze]] [[river|River]].
# {{lb|zh|geography|by extension}} A [[river]].
# {{surname|lang=zh|dot=:}} [[Jiang]] (''mainland China''), [[Chiang]] (''Taiwan''), [[Kong]] (''Hong Kong'')

====Usage notes====
The original Chinese word for "river" was {{zh-l|水}}, literally "water". In time, the proper name {{zh-l|河}} was used as a word for rivers and its original bearer distinguished as the {{zh-l|黃河|[[Yellow River]]}}. Similarly, {{zh-l|江}} was originally the name of the [[Yangtze]] [[river|River]] and then applied broadly as a generic word for rivers. In modern Chinese, {{zh-l|江}} are usually the larger rivers, {{zh-l|河}} are smaller rivers or [[creek]]s, and {{zh-l|水}} are [[brook]]s and [[stream]]s; but there are many exceptions to this general pattern owing to historical reasons.
